--- Chad Bohannan <chad@...> wrote:
> > OK, a lot of talk is of some value, but action
> speaks 
> > much louder. In this case the action needed is an
> ANN 
> > that can be presented with a random sequence of
> binary 
> > patterns, and then repeats them back one at a
> time. 
> > It could be in reverse order, or in the order of 
> > presentation. Each pattern might be 16 bits, or
> maybe 
> > only 8 or 10. 
> 
> > The model is a human who is told to dial a phone 
> > number, and then dials it. 
> 
> This is not the form of memory I'm trying to
> develop. I'll try to 
> explain. 
> A human is very advanced form of intelligence and
> remembering 
> a sequence if a very machine-like process. I don't
> think I'm a 
> very stupid human, and more than five or six ones
> and zero's in 
> a row is not only very difficult to remember, ( I
> would have to 
> explicitly apply heuristics like grouping and rhythm
> ), it's also 
> totally meaningless. 
> Like Ion said, doing a small part of a task is
> really really hard, 
> but looking at the task as a whole starts to make
> sense. What 
> do we need this sequence of bits for? 
> If I were going to dial the phone number, ( because
> I have a 
> terrible memory ) I would first find a way to record
> the number 
> to a long term memory ( like pen and paper or palm
> pilot ) then 
> use the phone and the paper together to make the
> call. 
> these are learned behaviors in long term memory, but
> while 
> the behavior of 'make the phone call' is being
> carried out, there 
> is short term memory of where the paper is. I never
> had to store 
> any sequences of numbers to my own long term memory.
> 
> 
> Do you see the difference in the kind of memory I'm
> describing? 
> In the future, I think the integration of long term
> memory with 
> short term memory will make for very powerful
> systems. I just 
> don't think we fully understand short term memory
> yet. 

No, I don't understand your objective.  Mine is clear
and simple, to demonstrate that a recurrent neural
network can do what animals frequently do, which is
remember a sequence of patterns, and then recall them
in order.  The telephone dialing task is an easy to
understand example of this.  (and most people can hear
a 7 digit number and immediately dial it, showing that
they remembered it at least briefly.)  Animals do it
when they remember a route and then find their way
back.  I'm not aware that this has been done by any
ANN researcher.  I plan to do it after my next two
releases, so It's likely to be in the early fall.  One
of you NEAT people could beat me to it if you got
crackin'. :)

=====
Mitchell Timin
